images.place: Tim Ho Wan, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Chinese fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) is cooked rice that has been cooled and then stir-fied with meats and vegetables (often leftovers).

**Eating Tip**

Don't feel obligated to try eating fried rice with chopsticks. In Asia, fried rice is often eaten with a spoon. It's a lot easier!

**Cooking Tip**

It's often advised to use day-old refrigerated rice which has dried out somewhat and won't be a sticky clump like freshly-cooked rice (in fact, fried rice originated as a way to reuse leftover rice).Although Danny Bowien in his [Mission Chinese Food Cookbook](https://www.harpercollins.com/products/the-mission-chinese-food-cookbook-danny-bowienchris-ying?variant=32208106618914) advocates frying freshly-cooked rice.

**Food Safety Tip**

Rice spoils quickly, so don't leave it out at room temperature too long

**Characters**

[炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice* (specifically, cooked rice), so [炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice*.

images.place: Banana Leaf Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) mixed with seafood.

**Characters**

[海鮮](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B5%B7%E9%AE%AE) means *seafood* ([海](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%B5%B7) is *ocean* and [鮮](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%AE%AE) is *fresh*, so *seafood* is literally *ocean fresh*). [炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice* ([炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice*), so 海鮮炒飯 is *seafood stir-fried rice*.

[Yanghzhou fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yangzhou_fried_rice), often listed as *Yang Chow fried rice* or just the restaurant's *house fried rice* (or in the UK, *special fried rice*), is [fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) mixed with scrambled egg, shrimp and barbequed pork or Chinese sausage. The ingredients vary, but this dish is distinguished by including multiple meats, whereas most Chinese fried dishes feature a single protein (pork fried rice, chicken fried rice, shrimp fried rice...).

**Trivia**

The city of [Yanghzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yangzhou) celebrated their 2500th anniversary (that's right, 2500 years!) by assembling around 300 cooks to prepare over 9000 pounds of their namesake dish in a bid to enter the Guinness World Records as the largest serving of fried rice, but the batch was disqualified as a portion was considered inedible (at least to humans - some of it went to livestock).

**Characters**

[揚州](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/揚州) is Yangzhou, the city in China where this dish originated. [炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice* ([炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice*), so [揚州炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/揚州炒飯) is *Yangzhou stir-fried rice*.

[Fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) mixed with Chinese sausage.

**Characters**

[臘腸](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%87%98%E8%85%B8) is *Chinese sausage*, [炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice* ([炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice*), so 臘腸炒飯 is *Chinese sausage stir-fried rice*.

[Fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) mixed with chunks of BBQ pork, and typically with scrambled eggs and peas. Often listed as “pork fried rice.”

**Characters**

[叉燒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8F%89%E7%87%92) is *BBQ pork*, [炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice* ([炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice*), so 叉燒炒飯 is *BBQ pork stir-fried rice*.

[鹹](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%B9%B9) is *salty*, [魚](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%AD%9A) is *fish*, [雞](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%9B%9E) is *chicken*, [炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice* ([炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice*), so 鹹魚雞炒飯 is *salty fish chicken stir-fried rice.*

[炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice* ([炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice*), so 午餐肉炒飯 is “*lunch meat stir-fried rice*.

images.place: JJ Noodle Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Billionaire fried rice](https://www.wokandkin.com/dried-scallop-and-egg-white-fried-rice/) is named (in English) for a Hong Kong billionaire who wanted a healthy fried rice recipe, and the result is this [fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) mixed with dried scallops and egg whites..

**Characters**

The Chinese name for this dish is more literal. [瑤柱](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *dried scallops*, [蛋白](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%9B%8B%E7%99%BD) is *egg white*, [炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice* ([炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice*), so 瑤柱蛋白炒飯 is *dried scallops and egg white stir-fried rice*.

images.place: C&K Chinese Kitchen, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
Also known as [Hokkien fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hokkien_fried_rice), this is [fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) with scrambled egg, covered with thick gravy typically containing seafood, poultry, mushroom, and vegetables.

**Characters**

福建 is Fujian, a province on the southeast coast of China, [炒飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92%E9%A3%AF) is *stir-fried rice* ([炒](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%82%92) is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and [飯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A3%AF) is *rice*), so 福建炒飯 is *Fujian stir-fried rice*.
